However, Petrograd, now called St. Petersburg, experienced significant changes in its architecture since the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991. One of the most significant shifts was the revival of pre-revolutionary architectural styles such as Art Nouveau, Art Deco, and Neoclassicism.

After the Soviet regime, there was a push to restore some of the city's pre-revolutionary buildings, which were destroyed or neglected during Soviet times. This led to extensive renovation works on historic buildings such as the Bolshoi Drama Theatre, Catherine Palace, and the Kazan Cathedral.

Also, new buildings constructed after the Soviet collapse reflected a move towards Western-style architecture, with glass and steel being the predominant materials used. The construction of the Lakhta Center is an example of this trend, as the skyscraper features a modern design that is unique compared to the city's historic architecture.

In summary, the post-Soviet period saw a mix of revival and modernization of architectural styles. Nonetheless, the city's historical architecture still remains a fundamental element of its identity, making St. Petersburg a unique blend of old and new architectural styles.

As an AI language model, I do not possess personal opinions; however, some buildings in St. Petersburg are widely regarded as being among the most beautiful in the city. The most popular ones are:

- The Winter Palace: This grand palace was the official residence of the Russian monarchs from 1732 to 1917. Today, it houses the famous Hermitage Museum.

- The Church of the Savior on Spilled Blood: This church is one of the most recognizable landmarks of St. Petersburg. It was built on the site where Emperor Alexander II was assassinated in 1881.

- The Kazan Cathedral: The construction of this cathedral began in 1801 and finished in 1811. It is dedicated to the Virgin of Kazan, a holy icon of the Russian Orthodox Church.

- St. Isaac's Cathedral: This magnificent cathedral is one of the largest in Russia and features an impressive dome that dominates the city skyline.

- The Peter and Paul Fortress: This is the original citadel of St. Petersburg and was founded in 1703 by Peter the Great. Today, it houses several museums and exhibitions.

These are just a few examples of the many stunning architectural wonders to be found in St. Petersburg.

Indeed, the Church of the Savior on Spilled Blood, also known as the Church of the Resurrection of Jesus Christ, is a true landmark of St. Petersburg. Its colorful and intricate domes are one of the most photographed and iconic images of the city.

The church was built between 1883 and 1907 on the spot where Emperor Alexander II was assassinated in 1881. Its unique style blends elements of traditional Russian architecture with influences from Byzantine and Gothic styles. The interior of the church is just as impressive, featuring intricate mosaics covering the walls and ceilings depicting scenes from the Bible and the life of Jesus Christ.

Unfortunately, the church suffered significant damage during the Soviet period and was used as a warehouse for many years. It was not until the 1970s that restoration works began, and in 1997 it was finally opened to the public. Today, it is considered one of St. Petersburg's most treasured architectural gems, visited by thousands of tourists every year.

St. Petersburg is full of hidden gems that are less well-known but equally impressive. Here are some of the most noteworthy:

- Mikhailovsky Castle: Built by Emperor Paul I and designed to look like a medieval fortress, this castle is located in the heart of St. Petersburg and is now a museum.

- Yusupov Palace: This 18th-century palace was the former residence of one of Russia's wealthiest families and features ornate interiors and a beautiful theater.

- Alexandrinsky Theater: This theater is one of the oldest and most famous in St. Petersburg, with a rich history and a beautiful neoclassical façade.

- The Bronze Horseman: This statue of Peter the Great on a rearing horse is a symbol of the city and is said to possess magical powers.

- St. Michael's Castle: This castle was built by Paul I and is known for its impressive architecture and beautiful gardens.

These are just a few examples of the hidden gems to be found in St. Petersburg. There are many more to explore, so don't be afraid to venture off the beaten path and discover the city's hidden treasures.
